Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Story:
My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. It was 2:13 a.m. I squinted at the screen—Sam. I answered, and his voice was raw, trembling. He could barely get the words out: his dad had collapsed, and the doctors weren’t hopeful. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to listen, to be present, to offer the comfort he needed. I knew he had no one else to call at this hour.

But as I murmured reassurances, my work phone lit up with a string of urgent messages. The external inspector had flagged a critical safety issue on the line I was responsible for. If I didn’t respond immediately, the plant could be shut down by morning, costing the company thousands and putting my team’s jobs at risk. My mind raced—protocol demanded my full attention, but Sam’s pain was so real, so immediate. I felt torn in two, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I leaned. Sam’s sobs filled my ear, while the insistent ping of work notifications reminded me of the consequences if I failed to act. I sat there, paralyzed, caught between being the friend Sam desperately needed and the engineer my team depended on.
